channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: How Rich Is Rishi Sunak, Britain’s New Prime Minister?
item.description: Just how rich is the new prime minister of Britain?
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:credit: Ian West/PA Image, via Alamy
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, at a reception in February for the British Asian Trust in London.

item.title: Why Natural Gas Prices in Europe Are Plunging
item.description: A combination of full storage, lower demand and mild weather, among other factors, has eased concerns of a spike in heating and power prices — for now.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Clara Vannucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: A regasification facility for liquefied natural gas in Porto Venere, Italy.

item.title: As Republicans Campaign on Crime, Racism Is a New Battlefront
item.description: Running ads portraying Black candidates as soft on crime — or as “different” or “dangerous” — Republicans have shed quiet defenses of such tactics for unabashed defiance.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman

item.title: New York’s Governor’s Race Is Suddenly Too Close for Democrats’ Comfort
item.description: Tightening polls, fears about crime and apathy in their base are driving a wave of Democratic hand-wringing and a pivot by Gov. Kathy Hochul.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Thalia Juarez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has shifted her campaign message to focus more on concerns over crime.

item.title: Adidas Ends Partnership With Kanye West After Antisemitic Comments
item.description: The German sportswear giant is the latest company to cut ties with the rapper and designer after his recent antisemitic outbursts and other provocations. Ending the long-running partnership is expected to put a big dent in profit at Adidas.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman, Michael J. de la Merced and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Jonathan Leibson/Getty Images North America
item.media:description: Kanye West, now known as Ye, in Hollywood in 2016 at an event promoting his partnership with Adidas.

item.title: Kanye West, Dropped by CAA, Makes Adidas and Corporate Partners Squirm
item.description: The antisemitic outbursts and provocations by the artist now known as Ye have raised questions about how much offensive behavior companies are willing to tolerate from a proven moneymaker.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario, Vanessa Friedman, Jessica Testa and Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kanye West, now known as Ye, in New York last month. After several weeks of outbursts on social media and in interviews, several brands and designers have been distancing themselves from him.

item.title: Why the Price of Gas Has Such Power Over Us
item.description: “When prices go up, we have this feeling of oppression that we can’t do everything we want.”
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Eve Washington
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A gas station near Truth or Consequences, New Mexico, in August. In a way, gas prices are like a giant scoreboard for the economy.

item.title: With Promise of Legalization, Psychedelic Companies Joust Over Future Profits
item.description: Cash rich start-ups are filing scores of patent claims on hallucinogens like magic mushrooms. Researchers and patient advocates worry high prices will make the therapies unaffordable.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: George Goldsmith, co-founder and executive chairman of Compass Pathways in London.

item.title: For Disabled Workers, a Tight Labor Market Opens New Doors
item.description: With Covid prompting more employers to consider remote arrangements, employment has soared among adults with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Sarah Rice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before the pandemic, Kathryn Wiltz repeatedly asked her employer to let her work from home because of her disability, but was denied.

item.title: James Corden and the Dangers of Likability
item.description: No one knows what an egg yolk omelet is, but we all know that TV hosts should be relatable. Or should they? That didn’t do Ellen DeGeneres any favors.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.category: The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Corden at a Tony Awards party in 2019. He presents himself as an ordinary bloke but is actually a Broadway star well known in Britain before arriving in the United States.

item.title: James Corden Addresses His Restaurant Ban
item.description: The “Late Late Show” host said he shouldn’t have been rude to a server at Balthazar in New York. “I hope I’m allowed in again one day,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)

item.title: Brunswick Stew Is the Perfect Soup for Right Now
item.description: Soul-warming, savory and sweet, this dish with a deep history is perfect for right now.
item.dc:creator: Eric Kim
item.media:credit: Jennifer Chase for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicken is most commonly used today, though some stew experts throw in beef chuck or pork shoulder for flavor and fat.

item.title: The John Fetterman-Mehmet Oz Debate: The Midterms in Miniature
item.description: This may be the Pennsylvania candidates’ last big chance for a breakout performance — or a catastrophic belly flop.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photographs by Mark Makela, via Getty Images

item.title: Rishi Sunak Won’t Save Britain
item.description: The country’s next prime minister is out of touch.
item.dc:creator: Kimi Chaddah
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters

item.title: Stroke and John Fetterman: What Society Should Know About the Brain’s Ability to Heal
item.description: What society can learn from John Fetterman’s stroke.
item.dc:creator: Jill Bolte Taylor
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania campaigning in Greensburg, Pa., in May.

item.title: Trumpism Beyond Trump
item.description: Which version of the Republican Party will win out?
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: How Europe’s Energy Crisis Exposed Old Fault Lines and New Anxieties
item.description: The cost-of-living situation on the continent is worse than it has been in a long time. That kind of economic pain could have political consequences.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Marc Georges, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A dim Eiffel Tower last month. The Paris authorities began switching off ornamental lights on monuments earlier than usual as part of a plan to cut energy use by 10 percent this winter.

item.title: If These Poll Results Keep Up, Expect Anything on Election Night
item.description: The current range of numbers could translate to a Democratic hold in the Senate, or an overall Republican rout.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Are You Being Flooded With Political Text Messages? We Want to See Them.
item.description: Candidates and advocacy groups are inundating voters’ phones with political text messages. Tell us about your experiences.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Ashton B. Carter, Defense Secretary Under Obama, Dies at 68
item.description: Trained as a physicist, he opened the U.S. military to transgender service members and removed barriers to women in combat roles.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joshua Roberts/Reuters
item.media:description: Ashton B. Carter in 2016, near the end of his term as secretary of defense.

item.title: Venezuelan Migrants Stranded After US Border Policy Change
item.description: They have sold their belongings and trekked across a deadly jungle. Now, tens of thousands Venezuelan migrants are stranded south of the United States, with nowhere to go.
item.dc:creator: David Shortell and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelan migrants on a hill near the border with United States in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. The United States has started turning back many Venezuelans reaching the border.

item.title: On Car-Free Streets, Many New York Restaurants Thrived
item.description: By promoting outdoor dining, the city’s Open Streets program has helped some eating and drinking establishments survive the pandemic, a new report finds.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu
item.media:credit: Sebastian Mejias for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Brooklyn, neighbors started a six-block Open Street on Vanderbilt Avenue in 2020. Now, 24 restaurants offer outdoor dining there.

item.title: Deadly Israeli Raid Targets New Palestinian Militia
item.description: At least six Palestinians were killed in a night of violence in the West Bank, raising tensions further ahead of elections in Israel next week.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Majdi Mohammed/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the bodies of Palestinians who were among those killed in an overnight Israeli raid in the occupied West Bank city of Nablus on Tuesday.

item.title: Home Remedies for Cold and Flu Symptoms
item.description: Here’s what we know about some of the most popular remedies that show at least a little promise.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Molly Matalon for The New York Times

item.title: Why Does Alcohol Mess With My Sleep?
item.description: Tips for getting a better night’s rest when your evening plans include drinking.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What Your Dog’s Behavior Means
item.description: Dogs are “really good at reading our emotions,” says one expert. But we’re not so good at reading theirs.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What is Microdosing, and Does it Work?
item.description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
item.dc:creator: Dana G Smith
item.media:credit: River Cousin

item.title: ‘Guillermo del Toro’s Cabinet of Curiosities’ Review: 7 Tricks, 1 Treat
item.description: Guillermo del Toro’s horror anthology for Netflix doesn’t hand out many scares.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.category: Guillermo del Toro's Cabinet of Curiosities (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Ken Woroner/Netflix
item.media:description: F. Murray Abraham in the episode “The Autopsy,” which benefits from his melancholy performance as a coroner who discovers something unexpected.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
